Chapter on Skill in Wholesome Factors, Chapter 3. Next, within the nine topics and so forth of this treatise, one should thoroughly understand the seven kinds of skill.
What are the seven?
Verse:ğŸ”½With regard to the aggregates, realms, and sense bases,
and the dharmas of dependent arising,
skill in place, non-place, faculties, and truths, one should understand the topics.
Discussion:
One who abides in the true Dharma should thoroughly understand these seven kinds of skillful topics.
Question:
Why are only seven kinds of skill established?
Answer:
Foolish worldlings often conceive in this way.
Verse:
The self, the master, and so forth, without cause, the self abides,
Transmigrates, creates various actions, and is of two kinds of dominance.
Discussion:
Because they are not skilled in the aggregates, those who grasp the substance of the aggregates as their body.

Because they are not skilled in the elements, they grasp the self and others as the cause of the arising of the body, or they grasp that the body arises naturally without a cause, because they do not understand that the body arises from its own seeds.
Why is this?
Because the elements are called functions, seeds, and causes of the family and so on.
Because they are not skilled in the sense bases, they grasp that there is a possessor of the body who relies on the body and abides in it, and grasps external objects.
Because they are not skilled in dependent origination, they grasp that the possessor of the body transmigrates through birth and death.
Because they do not understand what is possible and impossible, they grasp that the possessor of the body is able to create karma.

Because they are not skilled in the faculties and truths, they grasp two kinds of superior possessors of the body, namely, the superior one of the results of karma that is loved or not loved, and the superior one of defilement and purification.
Due to not understanding the two truths of suffering and its origin, there are those who consider defilements to be supreme.
Due to not understanding the two truths of cessation and the path, there are those who consider purity to be supreme.
Verse:
Arising in the body and self, the real self-abiding,
The transmigrator, the doer, and the various supreme meanings.
Defilement and purity give rise to seven kinds of foolishness.
The antidotes to these should be known as subsuming seven kinds of skillful means.
The Treatise says:

As previously generally explained, the two kinds of supremacy are specifically shown to be two kinds of foolishness, namely, foolishness regarding the supreme meaning and foolishness regarding defilement and purity.
Who, relying on the seven kinds of body, etc., turns to delusion?
Verse:
Falsely imagining the self of the body, relying on the various faculties and abiding,
Turning in the realms of objects, experiencing what is loved and not loved.
The basis of verbal expression, the doer, the one who has awareness,
Because of seeing one body in the differentiated aggregates.
The treatise says:
The ignorant, not understanding the nature of the form aggregate, imagine there is one self that relies on the five sense faculties and operates on objects.
Not understanding the nature of the feeling aggregate, they imagine there is a subject of experience that experiences all things that are loved or not loved.

Not understanding the nature of the conceptualization aggregate, they separately imagine there is a self that abides in verbal expression, not knowing that conceptualization is the basis of verbal expression.
As the Blessed One said:
As conceptualization arises, so verbal expression arises.
Not understanding the nature of the karmic formation aggregate, they imagine there is an agent.

Not understanding the nature of the consciousness aggregate, they imagine there is a knower. It is not only consciousness, because in the world, conceptualization arises in relation to the nature of the consciousness aggregate.

In this way, the ignorant, in the specific characteristics of the differentiated aggregates, generally give rise to one kind of delusion about the possessor of a body, and they imagine the possessor of a body to be the self.
Next, the ignorance of origination.
Verse:
Confused about the initial cause, they conceive of a permanent cause or no cause.
Commentary:
Ignorant worldlings, confused about the initial cause of their bodies, therefore grasp at unequal causes, namely, the permanent, sovereign, and self-existent gods as causes.
Some say there is no cause, denying the existence of any generative cause.
Next, the ignorance of the support of the real self.
Verse:
The self supports the faculties, is able to touch and experience.
Commentary:
Conceiving of the self as supporting the faculties, able to touch agreeable and disagreeable sensations, and to experience pleasure and pain.
Next, the ignorance of the supremacy of the creator of cyclic existence and of defilement and purification, namely, the conception of a separate, embodied self, verse:
From here, at death, rebirth occurs, conceived as a transmigrator,
The doer of dharmas and non-dharmas, and their fruits and predominance.
Those who cultivate wrong practices, considering them to be defiled;
Those who cultivate right practices, falsely considering them to be liberation.
The treatise says:

Those ignorant ones, in various places of death and rebirth, consider there to be a real self that transmigrates in the flow of birth and death. This very real self creates the causes of dharmas and non-dharmas in the next world. This very real self freely enjoys the fruits of those causes, so the dharmas that are the fruits arise. This very real self, relying on the dharmas that are the fruits, cultivates wrong practices and considers them to be defiled, and cultivates right practices and considers them to be liberation.
The verse says:
Before the Buddha appeared in the world, such ignorance turned;
Because the Buddha appeared in the world, he taught the seven kinds of skillful means.
The treatise says:
Herein it is shown that, depending on such a time, the ignorance of non-Buddhists turns as it should.
Sentient beings return to cessation because of these seven kinds of skillful speech that are not shared with any of the non-Buddhists.
Here, as for the skillful means regarding the aggregates, the verse says:
Knowing the distinctions of the world and so forth, one can eliminate the conception of a unitary whole,
And thus be free from bondage and liberated, with no sentient beings to be found.
Many kinds and general summaries, with shared and distinct transformations,
The knowledge of augmentation and diminution - this should be known as the skillful means regarding the aggregates.
The treatise says:
Distinctions of the world and so forth refers to the distinctions in the essence of the aggregates, past and future, and so forth.
As the Blessed One said:
All forms, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, coarse or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near, and so forth, are explained in detail.
By means of supreme wisdom, one truly knows and thus abandons the conception of a unitary whole regarding the aggregates, which is precisely the return to cessation.
Moreover, the nature of a pudgala cannot be found among the aggregates.
Why is this?
A sentient being cannot be found in the aggregates, nor can a sentient being be found apart from the aggregates, nor can a sentient being be found liberated from the aggregates.
As the Blessed One said to Åšá¹›gÄlaka:
Do you see the TathÄgata in the form aggregate?
Do you see the TathÄgata in the consciousness aggregate?
Åšá¹›gÄlaka replied:
No, Gautama.
In this way, it is explained in detail.
In that sÅ«tra, it is said that the pudgala cannot be found either in the aggregates as a whole or in each of them individually.
Here, it is only briefly stated that it cannot be found in the five aggregates as a whole.

In this way, having understood the distinctions in the characteristics of form and so forth, and having been able to abandon the reifying grasping that is their antidote, one attains skill in the specific and general characteristics of the aggregates.
Moreover, the meaning of skandha is that of accumulation. To be well able to understand this meaning of accumulation is called the skill in the skandhas.
This meaning of accumulation is of four kinds, namely, the meaning of many kinds, the meaning of general summary, the meaning of co-occurring, and the meaning of increasing and decreasing.
Herein, the manifestation of the self-nature of the skandhas and the benefits of severing their hindrances is called the skill in the skandhas.
What is the skill in the dhÄtus?
Verse:
Because of seeing the three causes arising, it is called the skill in the dhÄtus.
From beginningless [time], from one's own seeds, many kinds arise.
Because of this and in this, the appropriator cannot be found.
Because of relying on one's own wisdom, one is able to remove inferiority.
Commentary:
Because of contemplating how the three dharmas of faculties, objects, and consciousness arise from their own causes, it is called the skill in the dhÄtus.
Why is it so?
Because those dharmas, from beginningless [time], arise from their own seeds, arise in many ways, and arise in various ways.
It should be known that the arising of many is as stated in the sutra:
Because of the non-singularity of realms.
The arising of various kinds is as stated in the sutra:
Because of the various realms.
Moreover, because the self that can grasp objects through the various faculties cannot be found, one can know that what is done is based on oneself, and not on MaheÅ›vara, etc.

Therefore, in all that one wishes to do, one should not give rise to inferiority. The cultivation of mastery is shown here. The essence of skill in the realms and the benefits of severing their hindrances are called skill in the realms.
What is skill in bases?
Verse:
Knowing all contacts and all feelings arise from the two kinds of doors,
Based on contact, one should know skill in bases.
Just as in the case of the Dharma realm and the heavenly realm, the later ones are based on the earlier ones,
By means of the conventional truth, one understands the two kinds of natures.
Commentary:ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
By thoroughly understanding the essence of the gateway of contact, two bases are established, namely the faculties and their objects.
In this way, it is called a base because it has the meaning of being able to give rise to [consciousness], just as in the world, the place where good dharmas are cultivated is called the Dharma base.
Moreover, by thoroughly understanding that feelings depend on contact, therefore contact is established as their base.
In this way, it is called a base because it has the meaning of being a place of residence, just as in the world, the place where heavenly images reside is called the heavenly base.

Moreover, when the two dharmas of contact and feeling arise, by means of conventional truth, two natures are understood, namely the one who contacts and the one who feels, because contact is able to contact and feeling is able to experience.
Herein it is shown that from the perspective of ultimate truth, the one who contacts and the one who feels are both unobtainable;
from the perspective of conventional truth, both are obtainable.
This is called skill in the bases.
What is skill in dependent origination?
A verse says:
Knowing that impermanence is not yet severed, the cause is able to give rise to various effects,
The similarity of one's own continuity is called skillful in dependent origination.
Although sentient beings cannot be obtained, there is abandonment and continuation,
Because of thoroughly understanding the four kinds of dependent origination.
The treatise says:
Being able to thoroughly understand that from the impermanent causes that have never been permanently severed, various fruits can be produced, is called skillful in dependent origination.
That is to say, as the sutra explains:
Because this exists, that exists. Because this arises, that arises.
In this order.
Moreover, one is able to thoroughly understand that from these causes, various dharmas of fruit are produced in one's own continuity, as the sutra explains:
It is not due to other conditions that there is old age and death, etc.
Moreover, one thoroughly understands that various dharmas of fruit are produced from similar causes, as the sutra explains:
One who engages in evil bodily actions can elicit an undesirable, unpleasant, unlikable, and disagreeable retribution in the body.
One who engages in excellent actions can elicit a desirable, etc. retribution that is the opposite of the above.
This is so, etc.

Furthermore, the continuity of the aggregates is called the one who abandons life and the one who continues to be reborn. The nature of the pudgala cannot be attained, because one skillfully understands the four kinds of profound dependent origination, namely, it does not arise from self, it does not arise from other, it does not arise from self and other, and it does not arise without a cause.
Herein, the essence of dependent origination and the benefits of severing its obstacles are revealed. This is called skill in dependent origination.
What is skill in proper and improper conditions?
Verse:
Not creating, not going, not attaining, the essence of the second and the rest does not transform,
Pure views have no remaining karma, not self, not sovereign, two.
Such wisdom can know skill in proper and improper conditions,
In the definite proper conditions for one's own fruits, other than this is said to be improper conditions.ğŸ”½Treatise:
Herein,

If one does not see a self that is sovereign with regard to cause and effect, this is called skill in the possible and impossible. That is to say, because one does not create, because one does not go, because one does not obtain, because the substance of the two does not change, because the substance of the other does not change, and because the remaining actions of pure vision do not exist.
What is meant by not creating?
It means not creating pure good conduct exclusively, and therefore there is no sovereign self.
What is meant by not going?
It means that apart from good conduct, one does not go to good destinies.
As a sutra says:
There is no place and no possibility for one who engages in evil bodily actions up to attaining birth in the heavens. This is definitely impossible, and so on at length.
What is meant by not obtaining?
It means that apart from the skillful means of the pure holy path, one definitely cannot obtain the ultimate purity subsumed within the fruits of the path.
As a sutra says:

There is no place and no possibility for one who does not completely sever the five hindrances up to not cultivating the seven factors of awakening to be able to correctly realize the end of suffering. This is definitely impossible.
How is it that the two bodies do not transform?
It means that there is no place or possibility where two TathÄgatas appear in the world simultaneously, and so on at length.
How is it that the other bodies do not transform?
It means that apart from the body of a man, there is definitely no other body that can become a wheel-turning king, and so on.
As the sutra says:
There is no place or possibility where a woman can become a wheel-turning sage king, and so on at length.
How is it that the pure view has no remaining karma?
It means as the sutra says:
There is no place or possibility where a person fully endowed with the correct view would take the life of another, and so on up to experiencing an eighth existence, this is definitely not possible.
That which is possible is for ordinary beings.
Here, what is meant by not doing is that the self that is conceived does not have mastery over causes.
Not obtaining applies to both causes and effects. The pure view having no remaining karma is also like this. The rest only apply to effects.
Moreover, in terms of proper and improper conditions, that which is definite in its own effect is called a proper condition, and that which is not so is called an improper condition.
By means of non-inverted wisdom, being skilled in this is called being skilled in proper and improper conditions.
Herein, the essence of being skilled in proper and improper conditions and the benefits of severing their hindrances are shown.
What is being skilled in faculties?
Verse:ğŸ”½In terms of grasping, birth, abiding,
defilement, and purification,ğŸ”½there is no view of self or other,
but in their fruits, there is predominance.ğŸ”½In such skillful means,
it is called being skilled in faculties,ğŸ”½namely, in terms of the predominance of grasping, birth, abiding,
defilement, and purification.
The treatise says:
If one does not see that the self is predominant in grasping and so forth, it is called being skilled in faculties.
Why is it so?ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

When we consider other causes and conditions apart from the self that is imagined, [we see that] in grasping and so forth, other causes and conditions are dominant. Therefore, the imagined self is unreasonable.

translated: As for the statement that the faculties are dominant in grasping and so forth, it means that the six faculties such as the eye are dominant in grasping the six objects, the two faculties of male and female are dominant in giving rise to continuity, the one faculty of life is dominant in the abiding of continuity, the five faculties of sensation are dominant in defilement, and the eight faculties such as faith are dominant in purity.
Herein, the essence of skill in the faculties and the benefits of severing their hindrances are revealed. This is called skill in the faculties.
What is skill in the truths?
Verse:
Because of the nature of suffering, and because of combination, it is unreasonable.
Because of no cause and because of cause, and because of five kinds of analogies.
Thus, because of following realization, one should know skill in the truths.ğŸ”½Herein, the essence of skill in the truths and the benefits of severing their hindrances are revealed.
Following the understanding of what has never been seen, the meaning of the causes and conditions that have not been received.
The treatise says:
Because one is able to contemplate well that the self is neither in accord with the principle of the two dharmas of defilement and purity, it is called the skillfulness in the truths.
What are the two?
Namely, because of the self-nature of suffering and because of being united with suffering.
What is meant by because of the self-nature of suffering?
If the self-nature of the self is suffering, is it without cause or with cause?
If it is without cause, it should always be defiled;
if it has a cause, it should be pure first and then defiled later, therefore it is not in accord with principle.
What is meant by because of being united with suffering?
It is said that the five analogies are all not in accord with principle.
Why is it so?
If it is said that suffering is united with the self, it should not be like two pieces of wood being united, because there is the fault of having a nature that is not inclusive and does not depart.
It is also not like sentient beings being united with wood, because there is the fault of departing.
It is also not like fire being united with firewood, because there is the fault of the nature being destroyed.
It is also not like clothing and dye co-mingling, because even a small part of the pure white color cannot be obtained on the self.
It is also not like the combination of mind and mental factors.
Why is this?
The mind is the grasper, and it can be called corresponding with this by the same object-condition, etc.;
But the self does not have this meaning, so it is not in accord with reason.

Moreover, seeing meanings that have never been seen before and their causes and conditions, and also seeing meanings that have never been experienced before and their causes and conditions, is called skill in the truths.

This means that from ancient times one has never clearly seen the two truths of suffering and its origin, as well as their causes and conditions. From ancient times, one has never clearly seen the two truths of cessation and the path that have never been experienced before, as well as their causes and conditions.
Herein, the essence of supramundane cognition and the benefits of severing its obstructions are revealed. This is called skill in the truths.
Verse:
It should be known that the distinctions of all skills are twenty-three,
Different from the treatises that take the Abhidharma as the basis, later they are most pure.
The treatise says:

It should be known that the distinctions of skill in aggregates, etc. are further of twenty-three kinds, namely: skill in the different inclusion treatises,ğŸ”½skill in the knowledge born of hearing, skill in the knowledge born of reflection,

skill in the knowledge born of cultivation,ğŸ”½skill in the knowledge of the factors leading to penetration, skill in the knowledge of the path of seeing, skill in the knowledge of the path of cultivation,
skill in the knowledge of the final path, skill in the knowledge of the development of faculties, skill in the knowledge of the development of spiritual powers,
skill in the knowledge of impure conventional truth, skill in the knowledge of pure conventional truth,
skill in ultimate truth, skill in the knowledge of impure conceptual characteristics,
skill in the knowledge of pure conceptual characteristics, skill in the knowledge of pure non-conceptual characteristics,

skill in the knowledge preceding the accomplishment of what is to be done, skill in the knowledge of the accomplishment of what is to be done, skill in the knowledge subsequent to the accomplishment of what is to be done, skill in the knowledge of Å›rÄvakas, skill in the knowledge of pratyekabuddhas, skill in the knowledge of bodhisattvas,
Skill in wisdom, and skill in the most extremely pure wisdom.
Herein, skill in the various treatises is also twofold: skill in the various kinds of inclusion, and skill in the various kinds of treatises.
Skill in the various kinds of inclusion is of eleven kinds, namely, inclusion by realms, up to mutual inclusion.

Inclusion by realms means that the aggregates, etc. are included by their own seeds.ğŸ”½Inclusion by characteristics means that the aggregates, etc. are included by their own specific and general characteristics.
Inclusion by kinds means that the aggregates, etc. are included by their own universal kinds.
Inclusion by states means that the aggregates, etc. are included by the states of being conducive to pleasant feeling, etc.
Inclusion by inseparability means that the aggregates, etc. are included by a single dharma, because their retinue is inseparable.
Inclusion by time means that the aggregates, etc. are each individually included by the past, future, and present.
As for comprehensive inclusion, it means that the aggregates and so forth rely on directions to arise and transform. If they arise in this direction, they are included in this direction.
Complete inclusion refers to the aggregates and so forth being fully included in the fifty-eight, twelve, and so forth.
Partial inclusion refers to the aggregates and so forth being included in each individual small part.
Ultimate inclusion refers to the aggregates and so forth being included in the characteristics of suchness.
Mutual inclusion refers to the aggregates and so forth mutually including each other.
Skill in various discourses means being skillful in various questions and answers regarding the aggregates and so forth, such as using a single action...
Question:
One should use the affirmative sentence, the negative sentence, the four-part sentence, and the meaningless sentence?
Answer:ğŸ”½For example, if there is a question, If there is inclusion in the realms, is there also inclusion in the characteristics?
If there is inclusion in the characteristics, is there also inclusion in the realms?

First, you should answer with four propositions regarding the eye. There may be those who are included in the realms but not in the characteristics, namely those born in the form realm who have not obtained the eye, or even if they have obtained it, have already lost it, or those ordinary beings born in the formless realm.
There may be those who are included in the characteristics but not in the realms, namely the final eye of an arhat.
There may be those who are included in the realms and also in the characteristics, namely those in the state of having eyes, excluding those mentioned above.

There may be those who are not included in the realms and also not in the characteristics, namely the destroyed and lost eye of an arhat, those born in the formless realm who have already seen the truths, and those who have already entered the realm of nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder.

As with the eye, this discrimination should be applied to all the others as appropriate.ğŸ”½As with the inclusion in the realms and the inclusion in the characteristics, the inclusion in the realms and the other inclusions should be broadly discriminated in this way, one by one.
As with the other inclusions and the other inclusions, excluding the previous and facing the subsequent, all should be broadly discriminated in this way, one by one, as appropriate.
Next, if a dharma is included in the aggregates, is that dharma also included in the realms?
If a dharma is included in the realms, is that dharma also included in the aggregates?
This should be answered using the first permutation: if a dharma is included in the aggregates, that dharma is also included in the realms.
Or a dharma may be included in the realms but not in the aggregates, namely the unconditioned dharmas.
Just as the aggregates are related to the realms, so the aggregates should be extensively discussed in terms of inclusion up to the truths, relying on the principle of one line.
Just as the aggregates are related to the other [categories], so the realms are related to the sense bases, etc., up to the faculties being related to the truths, should be extensively distinguished.
Among them, those skilled in the impure conventional wisdom are skilled in the wisdom of the factors leading to penetration.
Those skilled in the pure conventional wisdom are skilled in the mundane wisdom attained after the supramundane [wisdom].
Those skilled in the ultimate wisdom are skilled in the wisdom of the path of seeing.

These three kinds are skillful means of the impure cognition with discrimination that is not good, skillful means of the pure cognition with discrimination that is good, and skillful means of the pure cognition without discrimination that is good.

These three kinds are skillful means of the cognition that is the precursor to the accomplishment of what is to be done, skillful means of the cognition that accomplishes what is to be done, and skillful means of the cognition subsequent to the accomplishment of what is to be done.

Moreover, the distinctions among the first three kinds are: the arising of afflictions that have not yet been eliminated is not the antidote to afflictions, the arising of afflictions that have already been eliminated is not the antidote to afflictions, and the arising of afflictions that have already been eliminated is the antidote to afflictions.

The distinctions among the middle three kinds are: these three kinds are distinguished by whether they have discrimination or not, and by whether they are conventional cognition or ultimate cognition.

The distinctions among the last three kinds are: these three kinds are distinguished by whether they are the cognition that is the precursor to the elimination of afflictions, the cognition that is the path of right elimination, or the cognition at the time subsequent to that.
In this way, the nine knowledges are established based on the differences in the continuity and individual of persons. One should know that there are four kinds.

Chapter 4: Establishing Impermanence. Next, as previously stated, if one wishes to correctly cultivate the merits of complete understanding and so forth, it means completely understanding suffering and so forth.
How does one completely understand suffering?
It means completely understanding impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and non-self in the truth of suffering.
Now, in order, one should extensively establish this.
Among them, establishing impermanence means one should reveal the essence of impermanence and the distinctions of impermanence.
What is impermanence?
What are the distinctions?
The verse says:
Impermanence refers to the conditioned, because it is associated with the three characteristics.
The meaning of impermanence should be known as six or eight kinds according to the circumstances.
The treatise says:

As for the nature of impermanence, it refers to conditioned dharmas, because they are associated with the three characteristics of conditioned [dharmas]. The first is the characteristic of birth, the second is the characteristic of cessation, and the third is the characteristic of abiding and changing.
Moreover, the distinctions in the meaning of impermanence, as appropriate, should be known as either six or eight.
What are the six and eight?
The verse states:
Lack of intrinsic nature, destruction, transformation, separation, attainment, and future existence;
Instants, continuity, illness, etc., mind, vessel, and enjoyment.
The treatise states:

The six kinds of impermanence are: 1. impermanence of lack of intrinsic nature, 2. impermanence of loss and destruction, 3. impermanence of transformation, 4. impermanence of separation, 5. impermanence of attainment, and 6. impermanence of future existence.

The eight kinds of impermanence are: 1. the door of instants, 2. the door of continuity, 3. the door of illness, 4. the door of aging, 5. the door of death, 6. the door of mind, 7. the door of vessels, and 8. the door of enjoyment.

Among these, the two kinds of impermanence of momentariness and continuity are universal, while the three kinds of impermanence of sickness, etc. are internal to form, the impermanence of mind is only in name, and the two kinds of impermanence of the receptacle and enjoyment are external to form.
Among these, the impermanence of non-existence means that because the nature is always non-existent, it is called impermanent.
The remaining fifteen kinds of impermanence of transformation are as follows.
Verse:
It should be known that the fifteen kinds of transformation have distinctions,
Namely, the eight conditions of state, etc., are oppressed by conditions.
The lower realm has all, the middle realm lacks three gates,
And has three kinds of transformation, the upper realm further lacks the receptacle.
Commentary:
The fifteen kinds of transformation are: transformation of state, up to the transformation of the disappearance of all kinds.
The transformation of state means that from the state of infancy up to old age, the before and after are not similar, each having a separate transformation.
The manifest transformation refers to the transformation from beautiful color, fresh skin, and moist skin to the transformation into an ugly color, coarse skin, and withered skin.
The transformation of shape refers to the transformation of fat, thin, etc.
The transformation of prosperity refers to the prosperity of relatives, wealth, precepts, views, etc.
The opposite of this is called decline.
The transformation of limbs refers to the transformation from having all limbs to having incomplete limbs.
The transformation of cold and heat refers to the transformation of the body, such as curling up, trembling, sweating, and seeking cold and warmth, etc. in cold weather.
The transformation of being harmed by others refers to the transformation of the body, such as being kicked, bitten by mosquitoes and flies, etc.
The transformation of fatigue refers to the transformation of the body due to running, jumping, and leaping, etc.
The transformation of deportment refers to the transformation of gain and loss in the four deportments, such as walking, standing, sitting, and lying down.
The transformation of contact means that due to the transformation of contact that accords with suffering, happiness, etc., the feelings of suffering, happiness, etc. transform.
The transformation of defilement means that the mind is disturbed by the great and small afflictions such as greed and hatred.
The transformation of illness, etc. means that one who was previously without suffering becomes afflicted by a serious illness and the body transforms.
The transformation of death means that what was previously alive later becomes empty and without consciousness, with a transformation from before to after.
The transformation of blue-black, etc. means that after death, the body's color turns blue-black, swells up, rots, and even becomes a skeleton, etc., with a transformation.
The transformation of the disappearance of all kinds means that in the state of bones, when burned, destroyed, and scattered, all kinds are completely unseen, with a transformation.
Moreover, these fifteen kinds of transformations correspond to eight conditions.

The eight conditions are: 1. Accumulation over time, 2. Damage by others, 3. Diminution in enjoyment, 4. Passage of time, 5. Burning by fire, 6. Destruction by water, 7. Drying by wind, 8. Combination of different conditions.
Accumulation over time means that due to the passage of time, material dharmas naturally decay without leaving their original place.
Damage by others means various oppressive causes and conditions that lead to changes before and after.
Diminution in enjoyment means that for various objects of enjoyment, the individual owners' use and consumption lead to changes in diminution.

Passage of time means that in winter, it is cold and snowy, and in summer, it is hot and rainy, causing forests and herbs to flourish or wither.ğŸ”½Burning by fire means that when a great fire runs wild, cities, towns, and villages are all turned to ashes.
Destruction by water means that when great floods occur, villages and towns are all submerged.
That which is dried by wind refers to when a great wind blows and quickly dries up wet clothes and ground.

The combination of different conditions refers to when a person with much greed encounters the conditions for anger, at that time the entanglements of greed cease and the entanglements of anger arise.
It should be understood that it is the same for those with much anger and much delusion who encounter the conditions for other afflictions.
It is also like this for the different objects that appear to the various consciousnesses.
Next, the meaning of impermanence is complete in the desire realm.
In the form realm, except for the three kinds of impermanence of illness, aging, and enjoyment, there are also the three kinds of changes of contact, defilement, and death.
It should be known that the meaning of impermanence as explained in the form realm is the same in the formless realm, except for the realm of the container.
Verse:
The meaning of non-existence and impermanence is what is grasped by the imagination;
The remaining meanings of impermanence should be known as the dependent arising.
Treatise:
The meaning of impermanence subsumed by the meaning of non-existence should be known as subsumed by the characteristics of the imagined nature;
the remaining meanings of impermanence are subsumed by the characteristics of the dependent nature;
there is no meaning of impermanence in the characteristics of the perfected nature.
Thus, the distinctions in the meaning of impermanence and their subsumption by the three characteristics have been revealed.
Moreover, as the World-Honored One has said:
All that is impermanent is suffering.
What is the meaning of this?
The verse states:
All that is impermanent is suffering, because it is mixed with various sufferings;
Foolish ordinary beings, deluded about the nature of phenomena, are harmed by it without realizing it.
The treatise states:

Because impermanence is mixed with the suffering of coarseness and heaviness, this nature of impermanence is the suffering of conditioned existence, thus it is suffering, and because it is the basis for the suffering of change, it is suffering.
Therefore, the truth of the path is not suffering, because it is not mixed with the meaning of impermanence that has the characteristics of suffering.
In this nature of dharmas, deluded ordinary beings are unable to understand the meaning of permanence and impermanence, and are also harmed by the present impermanence they have already attained.
The previous explanation of momentary impermanence pervading all is not directly perceived by the world, and therefore it should be established.
Verse:
Because they are the fruits of the mind, having arisen they naturally cease,
Later changes can be obtained, and momentariness should be understood.
Commentary:
All conditioned forces are the fruits of the mind, and their nature, upon arising, is separated from causes of cessation and naturally decays.
Moreover, later changes can be obtained. One should understand that all conditioned forces are momentary and cease.
How should one understand that conditioned forces are the fruits of the mind?
Verse:
The superior perfuming of the mind, the transformation of samÄdhi, and mastery,
The principle of the arising of images, and the three kinds of holy teachings.
Commentary:
It is known through reasoning and the holy teachings that all conditioned things are the nature of the mind's effects.
Reasoning means that good and bad dharmas infuse the mind, and due to the power of the increase of the mind's perfuming, conditioned things are able to arise.
Moreover, for one whose mind is liberated and pure, all conditioned things follow the mind's transformation, due to the power of the freedom of their mental understanding.
Moreover, due to the power of the mind's freedom in samÄdhi, the images of the objects of the mind in samÄdhi arise as one wishes.
This is called reasoning.
The holy teachings refer to the three kinds of holy speech.

The mind leads the world, the mind is its protector. Arising from the mind, it all turns according to the mind.

Therefore, bhiká¹£us should be well concentrated and observe the mind according to the correct principle, and so on at length.

Bhiká¹£us should know that the lord of the city refers to the aggregate of consciousness with grasping.

Question:
How should one understand the principle of the natural destruction of those conditioned phenomena?
Answer:
It is due to four kinds of causes and conditions.
Verse:
Because the cause of arising is contradictory, there are no causes for abiding and cessation.
The error of permanent abiding, one should know that cessation is spontaneous.
Commentary:
The cause of arising cannot cause the cessation of conditioned phenomena, because arising and cessation are mutually contradictory.
Moreover, there is no cause for abiding that causes conditioned phenomena to abide. If there were necessarily such a thing, it would become permanent abiding.
Since conditioned phenomena do not abide, what need is there for a cause of cessation?
Moreover, the nature of another cause of cessation cannot be obtained.
If conditioned phenomena, having arisen, naturally abide, they would then necessarily abide permanently, resulting in a great error.
Thus, because there are errors in causes for abiding and cessation, as well as in spontaneous abiding, one should know that conditioned phenomena naturally perish and cease.
Verse:
Not by water, fire, or wind is there cessation, because they arise together with cessation;
After that corresponding cessation, the cause of the arising of other transformations.
The treatise says:
If water, fire, and wind are the causes of cessation, it is unreasonable, because they cease simultaneously.
If those water, etc. are the causes of cessation, then rotten, burned, and dried objects should not cease the previous continuity and then give rise to a continuity of transformations again.
Why is it so?
Because it is unreasonable for the cause of non-existence to be the cause of existence.
However, when water, fire, and wind correspond to the cessation of rotten, etc. objects, they can be the cause for the subsequent arising of those objects.
Apart from this function, water, etc. have no other power over them.
Furthermore, if one grasps the characteristic of cessation as the cause of cessation, is this characteristic of cessation simultaneous with the dharma that is to be ceased, or is it not simultaneous?
If so, what is the error?
The verse says:
The continuity of contradiction is severed, and the two characteristics become without characteristics.
Contradicting the present perception of the world, there is no dharma and other causes.
The treatise says:
If it is said that the characteristic of cessation and the dharma to be ceased exist simultaneously, that is not reasonable, because there is the fault of contradiction.
If it is said that they do not exist simultaneously, that is also unreasonable, because there is the fault of the discontinuity of their continuity.
Moreover, is the cause of cessation that which causes the cessation of dharmas, or is it not?
If it is cessation, then there would be two characteristics of cessation for a single dharma.
If it is not cessation, then there should be no characteristic of cessation.
There is this fault, so it is not reasonable.
Moreover, it contradicts what is commonly seen in the world, so one should not grasp cessation as the cause of destruction.
Why is this?
Because it is commonly seen in the world that other existent dharmas are the cause of destruction, and one does not see cessation as the cause of cessation.
Moreover, if cessation is the cause of cessation, does it only cause cessation by itself, or does it still need other conditions?
Both of these two causes have faults.
If cessation is only that which causes the cessation of dharmas, then when there is cessation, at that time the substance of dharmas would ultimately be nonexistent.
If it is necessary to wait for other conditions, then those other conditions should be the cause of destruction, and it should not be considered that cessation is the cause of destruction.
Next, how should one understand that because subsequent transformation can be obtained, dharmas perish in a moment?
Verse:
The body, breasts, forests, etc. do not have transformation without prior existence,
Nor is it that they are not destroyed at first, but perish only at the end.
Commentary:
All worldly internal and external dharmas such as the body, breasts, forests, etc. have transformation that can be obtained at the end.
Therefore, it is unreasonable that their substance does not change at an earlier time.
Moreover, it is not that they are not destroyed at an earlier time, but perish only at the end, because there is no different cause.

In this way, because it does not change before and does not change later, and because it does not perish before and does not perish later, it should be known that all conditioned phenomena are momentary and perish. Therefore, the meaning of the momentariness of those phenomena is established.
In this way, having established impermanence, all the eternal phenomena imagined by non-Buddhists, such as the self, ÄªÅ›vara, svabhÄva, atoms, and consciousness, are not established.
How is it that the self is not established as eternal?
The verse states:
Because of the distinctions in states, thoughts, and afflictions, it is not eternal and does not change.
If it does not change, then experience, action, and liberation are unreasonable.
The treatise states:
Because the imagined self has distinctions in states such as happiness and suffering, thoughts such as good and evil, afflictions such as greed and anger, and distinctions in time, it is impermanent.
Why is this so?
Because this imagined self, due to happiness and so forth, has some changes, it should not be eternal.

If it does not change at all, it should not be conceived as the experiencer, the creator, or the one who attains liberation, because the self and dharmas are not different in existence or nonexistence.
Moreover, there is also no independent, eternally abiding substance that can give rise to the world.
Why is this?
A verse says:
Because of the absence of function, inclusion and non-inclusion are contradictory,
The existence and non-existence of function lead to the fault of being a cause.
The treatise says:
The conceived independent [principle] has no ability to give rise to the world.

Verse:
The characteristics of change in self-nature, existence and non-existence are unreasonable,
Without distinction, impermanence, with distinction, five faults.
Without characteristics, also without causes, not eternally changing by self-nature,
Previously there was no change, I should be eternally liberated.
The Treatise says:
If it is calculated that self-nature is eternal, then it should not be a cause of change.
Why is this?
The calculated self-nature is neither a characteristic of existence with change, nor a characteristic of non-existence with change, therefore it is unreasonable.
If this intrinsic nature is not different from the other characteristics of change, it should be impermanent.
If there is a difference, it leads to five kinds of errors.
First, the error of having no characteristics, because apart from the characteristics of change, not even a small part of the intrinsic nature can be obtained.
Second, the error of not being a cause, because the world does not see any permanent dharma as the substance of the cause of arising.
Third, the error of not being the intrinsic nature, because the world does not see anything of a different kind as the intrinsic nature of that.
Fourth, the error of the intrinsic nature of permanence giving rise to change at all times, because it does not depend on other causes.
Fifth, the error of this intrinsic nature being liberated before the arising of change.
If it were so, then later on it should not give rise to various changes.
Furthermore, the idea that the ultimate atom is permanent is not reasonable.
Why is it so?
The verse says:
Permanence and production are unreasonable, due to two or three causes;
Wealth, sentient beings, and dominance, the ultimate atom is not permanent.
The treatise says:
The permanence and productivity of the ultimate atom are both unreasonable.
Why is permanence unreasonable?
Because of two reasons.
Is the nature of your ultimate atom permanent because of subtlety, or is it permanent because of being of a different kind?
If it is because of subtlety, because of being fine and weak, it should not be permanent.
If it is because of being of a different kind, this characteristic cannot be obtained.
It is unreasonable to say that non-earth, etc. produces earth, etc.
Why is productivity unreasonable?
Because of three reasons: first, because of direction, second, because of causes and conditions, third, because of its own nature.
Why is it unreasonable because of direction?
That is to say, when producing coarse things from ultimate atoms, is it beyond their measure, or is it not beyond?
If it does not extend beyond, then coarse matter should be like atoms, which cannot be grasped.
Moreover, the world does not see obstructive and unilluminated objects occupying the same place, so this is unreasonable.
If it extends beyond, then the place where it extends beyond, the coarse matter, not being composed of atoms, should be permanent.
If one further imagines that other atoms are produced, then the atoms should not be permanent.
Why?
Because of causes and conditions.
If you imagine that the nature of combination is the cause and condition for establishing other things and causing them to combine, is this nature of combination produced or not yet produced?
If it is produced, then after the combination of combined objects, no difference in the nature of combination can be found, so this is unreasonable.
If it is not yet produced, then it has no substance.
A non-substantial cause is unreasonable.
Why?
Because of its own substance.
When these atoms form gross objects, it should not be like seeds producing sprouts.
Because atoms should be destroyed, like seeds.ğŸ”½It should not be like milk, because atoms should transform.
It should not be like a potter, because the activity of atoms cannot be obtained.
Therefore, formation is unreasonable.

Although there are no permanent atoms, there are the arising of the enjoyed objects of the world at the beginning of the eon, due to the dominant power of the karma of sentient beings, not due to atoms.
Therefore, the permanence of atoms is unreasonable.
Next, the assertion of the existence of permanent cognition is unreasonable.
Why is it so?
The verse states:
Without permanence as their basis, they arise in sequence and with distinctions.
Because feelings and so forth are different, cognition should be known as impermanent.
The treatise states:

Because visual consciousness and so forth arise in dependence on the impermanent eye and so forth, because they evolve in sequence with regard to objects such as form, because they evolve with many different aspects, and because they differ in states such as pleasure and so forth, craving and so forth, and good thoughts such as giving and so forth.
It is unreasonable that a single permanent consciousness should evolve in this way.
Why is it that sentient beings in the world do not grasp the existence of impermanence, and why do they grasp the nonexistence of permanence in various ways?
A verse says:
Ignorance of impermanence is the root of the four inversions.
One should know that in the world, the power of delusion increases.
The treatise says:
Because ignorance of impermanence arises, one does not grasp the existence of impermanence, and various attachments to the nonexistence of impermanence arise.
Not only is the inversion of permanence caused by ignorance, but the four inversions all have ignorance as their root.
Why is this?

Because of not knowing impermanence as it truly is, one gives rise to the inversion of permanence regarding impermanent dharmas, the inversion of happiness regarding suffering, the inversion of purity regarding impurity, and the inversion of self regarding non-self.
Because there is this sequence of meaning, the BhagavÄn said:
If a dharma is impermanent, it must be suffering. If a dharma is suffering, it must be non-self.

One should know that when one advances by means of the worldly path, one does not eliminate ignorance but gradually advances to higher stages, and the power of delusion regarding the nature of impermanence becomes even greater.
Why is this?
Because in the desire realm, the characteristics of impermanence such as destruction, change, and separation are clearly perceptible, but not in the higher stages.
Moreover, what is the reason for the arising of ignorance regarding impermanence?
The verse says:
Laziness, seeing, dullness, lack of provisions,
Bad friends, and non-right Dharma should be known as the causes of ignorance.
The treatise states:

There are seven kinds of causes for not knowing impermanence: 1. carelessness, 2. laziness, 3. inverted views, 4. ignorance, 5. not having accumulated much merit for enlightenment, 6. evil friends, and 7. hearing incorrect teachings.
Because one is careless regarding the pleasures of the senses and the bliss of meditation, one does not truly understand the nature of impermanence.

Even if one is not careless, one may still be lazy; even if one is not lazy, one may still have inverted views; even if one does not have inverted views, one may still be ignorant; even if one is not ignorant, one may still not have accumulated merit for enlightenment; even if one has cultivated merit for enlightenment, one may still follow evil friends; and because one hears incorrect teachings from them, one does not truly understand impermanence.
What other causes are there for not understanding impermanence and mistakenly grasping at permanence?
The verse states:
Incorrect thought, remembering the past and so forth,
A similar continuity of existence, grasping at permanence in impermanence.
The treatise states:
One gives rise to the view of permanence due to two causes: first, by improper attention; second, by recollecting past events, etc.
Because past events, etc., continue to exist in a similar way, one also considers other worlds to be permanent.
Next, as previously stated, the three characteristics of conditioned phenomena are not limited to a single moment.
Why is this?
The verse states:
The first, last, and middle moments are taken as the three characteristics of conditioned phenomena.
The treatise states:
The three characteristics of conditioned phenomena are included in a single birth of the same type.

That is to say, at the initial birth, one takes it as the characteristic of birth; at the final death, one takes it as the characteristic of cessation; in the period of continuity between the two, one takes it as the characteristic of abiding and change.
One should understand that the establishment of the three characteristics of conditioned phenomena is like this.
The verse states:
One should know that the wisdom of subduing impermanence is due to two causes.
The treatise states:
The wisdom that accords with reality regarding the nature of impermanence enters by two causes:
One is by means of the foundations of mindfulness, and the other is by means of dependent origination.
By means of the foundations of mindfulness, one fixes the mind and makes it abide in various objects.
By means of dependent origination, one penetrates the nature of those dharmas.
As it is said in the sutra:
Seeing the arising of dharmas in the foundation of mindfulness of the body, and so on at length.
The verse states:
That seeing has six kinds, and dependent origination has four kinds.
The treatise states:
It should be known that the seeing of the nature of impermanence has six kinds.
The first is conventional knowledge, referring to the stage up to the stage of conformity with discernment.
The second is ultimate knowledge, referring to the stage up to the supramundane path.
The third is the knowledge of Å›rÄvakas, excluding the meaning of impermanence without nature.
The fourth is the knowledge of bodhisattvas, referring to the meaning of impermanence in everything.
The fifth is not well purified, referring to the knowledge of those two in training.
The sixth is well purified, referring to the knowledge of those two in no longer training.
Moreover, it should be known that the dharmas of dependent origination have four kinds of principles.
What are the four?
The verse states:
Because it arises from its own seeds, it is not from another. Because it depends on conditions, it is not from itself.
Because it has no creator, it is not from both. Because it has a function, it is not without a cause.
The treatise says:
One enters the nature of impermanence through four principles.
That is to say, conditioned dharmas do not arise from another, because they arise from their own seeds.
They also do not arise from themselves, because they depend on external conditions.
They also do not arise from both, because both are without activity.
They also are not without a cause, because those two have efficacy in arising.
